CVE-2021-44228
(10.0 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 97.56%

updated 2023-11-07T03:39:36.897000

2 posts

Apache Log4j2 2.0-beta9 through 2.15.0 (excluding security releases 2.12.2, 2.12.3, and 2.3.1) JNDI features used in configuration, log messages, and parameters do not protect against attacker controlled LDAP and other JNDI related endpoints. An attacker who can control log messages or log message parameters can execute arbitrary code loaded from LDAP servers when message lookup substitution is en

CVE-2022-26134
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 97.53%

updated 2023-08-08T14:22:24.967000

6 posts

In affected versions of Confluence Server and Data Center, an OGNL injection vulnerability exists that would allow an unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary code on a Confluence Server or Data Center instance. The affected versions are from 1.3.0 before 7.4.17, from 7.13.0 before 7.13.7, from 7.14.0 before 7.14.3, from 7.15.0 before 7.15.2, from 7.16.0 before 7.16.4, from 7.17.0 before 7.17

simontsui at 2024-03-06T15:44:48.702Z ##

Cado Security reports an emerging malware campaign targeting misconfigured servers running Apache Hadoop YARN, Docker, Atlassian Confluence and Redis for cryptocurrency mining. The campaign uses Golang-based malware that automate the discovery and infection of hosts. Confluence RCE vulnerability CVE-2022-26134 is exploited. Cado describes initial infection and the four Golang payloads. IOC provided.
🔗 https://www.cadosecurity.com/spinning-yarn-a-new-linux-malware-campaign-targets-docker-apache-hadoop-redis-and-confluence/

#threatintel #Apache #Hadoop #Redis #Docker #Confluence #Golang #IOC #cybercrime #cryptojacking #cryptominer #CVE_2022_26134 #XMRig

##

CVE-2021-36380
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 97.52%

updated 2024-03-06T03:30:28

8 posts

Sunhillo SureLine before 8.7.0.1.1 allows Unauthenticated OS Command Injection via shell metacharacters in ipAddr or dnsAddr /cgi/networkDiag.cgi.

Nuclei template

simontsui at 2024-03-05T18:47:57.860Z ##

In tracking the origins of exploitation leading up to their KEV Catalog additions:

  • I previously informed the CISA Vulnerability Management Team of potential exploitation of CVE-2021-36380 as part of an IZ1H9 Mirai-based DDoS campaign reported by Fortinet on 09 October 2023. What they do with that information is up to them.
  • The Pixel Update Bulletin published 13 June 2023 included an announcement that read "Note: There are indications that CVE-2023-21237 may be under limited, targeted exploitation."

#CISA #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #eitw #activeexploitation #vulnerability #CVE_2023_21237 #CVE_2021_36380

##
simontsui at 2024-03-05T16:07:00.301Z ##

Hot off the press! CISA adds 2 vulnerabilities to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog.
🔗 https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2024/03/05/cisa-adds-two-known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog

  • CVE-2023-21237 (5.5 medium) Android Pixel Information Disclosure Vulnerability
  • CVE-2021-36380 (9.8 critical) Sunhillo SureLine OS Command Injection Vulnerablity

CVE-2020-14882
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 97.52%

updated 2022-07-12T17:42:04.277000

4 posts

Vulnerability in the Oracle WebLogic Server product of Oracle Fusion Middleware (component: Console). Supported versions that are affected are 10.3.6.0.0, 12.1.3.0.0, 12.2.1.3.0, 12.2.1.4.0 and 14.1.1.0.0. Easily exploitable vulnerability allows unauthenticated attacker with network access via HTTP to compromise Oracle WebLogic Server. Successful attacks of this vulnerability can result in takeove

simontsui at 2024-03-06T15:17:04.396Z ##

ASEC reports that financially motivated threat actor z0Miner targets Korean Oracle WebLogic servers to cryptomine. z0Miner is known to exploit Oracle RCE vulnerabilities CVE-2020-14882 and CVE-2020-14883. ASEC provides the attack chain, from exploiting the vulnerabilities to deploy webshells, to using Fast Reverse Proxy (FRP) for Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) communication. Apache ActiveMQ vulnerability CVE-2023-46604 is also exploited. Netcat and AnyDesk are downloaded, and XMrig is used for mining. ASEC provides IOC, Monero Wallet and Mining Pool Address.
🔗 https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/62564/

#cybercrime #cryptojacking #threatintel #IOC #CVE_2020_14882 #CVE_2020_14883 #FRP #CVE_2023_46696 #z0Miner

CVE-2017-5754
(5.6 MEDIUM)

EPSS: 97.38%

updated 2021-11-19T18:15:08.547000

2 posts

Systems with microprocessors utilizing speculative execution and indirect branch prediction may allow unauthorized disclosure of information to an attacker with local user access via a side-channel analysis of the data cache.

ptesarik@fosstodon.org at 2024-02-29T13:55:17.000Z ##

Have you noticed that all public CNAs assign only negative numbers (like CVE-2017-5754)? So, what's with the positive CVE numbers (CVE+2024+xxxx)? They are assigned by secret CNAs! To hide even the fact there are any such CNAs, the positive-number CVEs must never be published.

Um, this conspiracy theory is even more stupid than flat Earth. So it may catch up…

##
ptesarik@fosstodon.org at 2024-02-29T13:55:17.000Z ##

Have you noticed that all public CNAs assign only negative numbers (like CVE-2017-5754)? So, what's with the positive CVE numbers (CVE+2024+xxxx)? They are assigned by secret CNAs! To hide even the fact there are any such CNAs, the positive-number CVEs must never be published.

Um, this conspiracy theory is even more stupid than flat Earth. So it may catch up…

##

CVE-2023-42793
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 97.34%

updated 2023-10-03T15:44:06.660000

2 posts

In JetBrains TeamCity before 2023.05.4 authentication bypass leading to RCE on TeamCity Server was possible

Nuclei template

5 repos

https://github.com/Zenmovie/CVE-2023-42793

https://github.com/LeHeron/TC_test

https://github.com/H454NSec/CVE-2023-42793

https://github.com/StanleyJobsonAU/GhostTown

https://github.com/johnossawy/CVE-2023-42793_POC

simontsui at 2024-03-05T16:42:41.230Z ##

Why you should care about the new JetBrains TeamCity authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2024-27198 (9.8 critical):

  • On 18 October 2023, Microsoft observed North Korean state-sponsored APTs Diamond Sleet (aka Lazarus Group, publicly attributed to 110 Research Center 3rd Technical Surveillance Bureau of Reconnaissance General Bureau by the US Government) and Onyx Sleet (aka Andariel, also publicly attributed to RGB by the US Government) exploiting a similar JetBrains TeamCity authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2023-42793.
  • On 13 December 2023, CISA published a cybersecurity advisory reporting that the Russian state-sponsored APT29 (Cozy Bear, publicly attributed to Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) by the USG) was mass-exploiting CVE-2023-42793 since September 2023.
  • From public disclosure to proof of concept was 6 days. Exploitation was within 7 days after that (KEV Catalog in 15 days). Nation-state abuse within 12-22 days of public disclosure.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

##
simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-03-05T16:42:41.000Z ##

Why you should care about the new JetBrains TeamCity authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2024-27198 (9.8 critical):

  • On 18 October 2023, Microsoft observed North Korean state-sponsored APTs Diamond Sleet (aka Lazarus Group, publicly attributed to 110 Research Center 3rd Technical Surveillance Bureau of Reconnaissance General Bureau by the US Government) and Onyx Sleet (aka Andariel, also publicly attributed to RGB by the US Government) exploiting a similar JetBrains TeamCity authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2023-42793.
  • On 13 December 2023, CISA published a cybersecurity advisory reporting that the Russian state-sponsored APT29 (Cozy Bear, publicly attributed to Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) by the USG) was mass-exploiting CVE-2023-42793 since September 2023.
  • From public disclosure to proof of concept was 6 days. Exploitation was within 7 days after that (KEV Catalog in 15 days). Nation-state abuse within 12-22 days of public disclosure.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

##

CVE-2024-21887
(9.1 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 97.30%

updated 2024-01-22T17:15:09.523000

14 posts

A command injection vulnerability in web components of Ivanti Connect Secure (9.x, 22.x) and Ivanti Policy Secure (9.x, 22.x) allows an authenticated administrator to send specially crafted requests and execute arbitrary commands on the appliance.

Nuclei template

13 repos

https://github.com/duy-31/CVE-2023-46805_CVE-2024-21887

https://github.com/raminkarimkhani1996/CVE-2023-46805_CVE-2024-21887

https://github.com/imhunterand/CVE-2024-21887

https://github.com/oways/ivanti-CVE-2024-21887

https://github.com/seajaysec/Ivanti-Connect-Around-Scan

https://github.com/TheRedDevil1/Check-Vulns-Script

https://github.com/mickdec/CVE-2023-46805_CVE-2024-21887_scan_grouped

https://github.com/tucommenceapousser/CVE-2024-21887

https://github.com/yoryio/CVE-2023-46805

https://github.com/gobysec/Goby

https://github.com/gobysec/GobyVuls

https://github.com/Chocapikk/CVE-2024-21887

https://github.com/Chocapikk/CVE-2024-21893-to-CVE-2024-21887

simontsui at 2024-03-08T13:41:14.938Z ##

Check Point Research (CPR) reports on a financially motivated threat actor called Magnet Goblin, that leverages "1-day" vulnerabilities in public facing applications. This included Ivanti Connect Secure CVE-2024-21887 within 1 day of Proof of Concept. CPR attributed Magento, Qlink Sense and possibly Apache ActiveMQ campaigns to Magnet Goblin. They also discovered a Linux version of a malware called NerbianRAT, and use of the WARPWIRE JavaScript credential stealer (unknown if there are overlaps with Mandiant's UNC5325 threat actor). Magnet Goblin uses MiniNerbian (a small Linux backdoor) and RMM tools like ScreenConnect and AnyDesk. IOC provided.
🔗 https://research.checkpoint.com/2024/magnet-goblin-targets-publicly-facing-servers-using-1-day-vulnerabilities/

#MagnetGoblin #cybercrime #threatintel #IOC #CVE_2024_21887 #CVE_2022_24086 #CVE_2023_41265 #CVE_2023_41266 #CVE_2023_48365 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_21893 #NerbianRAT #WARPWIRE #MiniNerbian #ScreenConnect #AnyDesk

##
simontsui at 2024-03-02T01:23:46.663Z ##

TechCrunch: NSA confirmed that hackers exploiting flaws in Ivanti’s widely used enterprise VPN appliance have targeted organizations across the U.S. defense sector.
🔗 https://techcrunch.com/2024/03/01/nsa-says-its-tracking-ivanti-cyberattacks-as-hackers-hit-us-defense-sector/

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_22024 #CISA #securityadvisory

##
0xThiebaut at 2024-03-01T14:51:22.738Z ##

We're still discovering further ramifications to #Ivanti's #PulseSecure vulnerabilities (#CVE_2023_46805 & #CVE_2024_21887). In February, we identified two new backdoors: #SparkCockpit & #SparkTar. Both backdoors employ selective interception of TLS communication, offer multiple degrees of persistence and access possibilities into the victim network (e.g., traffic tunneling through SOCKS proxy).

👀 Analysis & detection rules at https://blog.nviso.eu/2024/03/01/covert-tls-n-day-backdoors-sparkcockpit-sparktar/

The findings of our investigation have been independently corroborated by the research performed by Mandiant and have partially been observed by Fortinet.

#threatintel #forensics #reverseengineering

##
simontsui at 2024-02-29T18:13:43.608Z ##

Hot off the press! CISA along with FBI, MS-ISAC, Australia ASD ACSC, NCSC-UK, NCSC-NZ, Canadian Centre for Cyber Security and CERT NZ release joint cybersecurity advisory Threat Actors Exploit Multiple Vulnerabilities in Ivanti Connect Secure and Policy Secure Gateways. It includes TTPs, IOCs, and detection methods to help network defenders mitigate risk.
🔗 https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-060b

Of particular concern, the authoring organizations and industry partners have determined that cyber threat actors are able to deceive Ivanti’s internal and external Integrity Checker Tool (ICT), resulting in a failure to detect compromise.

During multiple incident response engagements associated with this activity, CISA identified that Ivanti’s internal and previous external ICT failed to detect compromise. In addition, CISA has conducted independent research in a lab environment validating that the Ivanti ICT is not sufficient to detect compromise and that a cyber threat actor may be able to gain root-level persistence despite issuing factory resets.

The authoring organizations strongly urge all organizations to consider the significant risk of adversary access to, and persistence on, Ivanti Connect Secure and Ivanti Policy Secure gateways when determining whether to continue operating these devices in an enterprise environment.

cc: @campuscodi @briankrebs @deepthoughts10 @serghei @selenalarson @DaveMWilburn

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_22024 #CISA #securityadvisory

##
simontsui at 2024-02-28T21:15:54.019Z ##

This line from Mandiant's article stuck out to me: "In addition, we have seen the threat actor demonstrate a nuanced understanding of the appliance and their ability to subvert detection throughout this campaign."

The reason is because of the following:

The internal ICT is configured to run in two-hour intervals by default and is meant to be run in conjunction with continuous monitoring. Any malicious file system modifications made and reverted between the two-hour scan intervals would remain undetected by the ICT. When the activation and deactivation routines are performed tactfully in quick succession, it can minimize the risk of ICT detection by timing the activation routine to coincide precisely with the intended use of the BUSHWALK webshell.

This sentence also concerns me, giving me flashbacks to Eclypsium's article

An encrypted version of BUSHWALK is placed in a directory excluded by the integrity checker tool (ICT)

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_22024

##
simontsui at 2024-02-27T19:45:07.447Z ##

Ivanti has a related blog post regarding evolving threat actor tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs). These findings were identified in the ongoing analysis of the previously disclosed vulnerabilities affecting Ivanti Connect Secure, Policy Secure and ZTA gateways, and include potential persistence techniques.
🔗 https://www.ivanti.com/blog/enhanced-external-integrity-checking-tool-to-provide-additional-visibility-and-protection-for-customers-against-evolving-threat-actor-techniques-in-relation-to-previously-disclosed-vulnerabilities

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_21893 #CVE_2024_22024

🔗 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/blog/investigating-ivanti-exploitation-persistence

cc: @campuscodi @iagox86 @brett

##

CVE-2023-46604
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 97.27%

updated 2023-11-28T15:15:07.597000

2 posts

The Java OpenWire protocol marshaller is vulnerable to Remote Code Execution. This vulnerability may allow a remote attacker with network access to either a Java-based OpenWire broker or client to run arbitrary shell commands by manipulating serialized class types in the OpenWire protocol to cause either the client or the broker (respectively) to instantiate any class on the classpath. Users

Nuclei template

simontsui at 2024-03-06T15:17:04.396Z ##

ASEC reports that financially motivated threat actor z0Miner targets Korean Oracle WebLogic servers to cryptomine. z0Miner is known to exploit Oracle RCE vulnerabilities CVE-2020-14882 and CVE-2020-14883. ASEC provides the attack chain, from exploiting the vulnerabilities to deploy webshells, to using Fast Reverse Proxy (FRP) for Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) communication. Apache ActiveMQ vulnerability CVE-2023-46604 is also exploited. Netcat and AnyDesk are downloaded, and XMrig is used for mining. ASEC provides IOC, Monero Wallet and Mining Pool Address.
🔗 https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/62564/

#cybercrime #cryptojacking #threatintel #IOC #CVE_2020_14882 #CVE_2020_14883 #FRP #CVE_2023_46696 #z0Miner

##
simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-03-06T15:17:04.000Z ##

ASEC reports that financially motivated threat actor z0Miner targets Korean Oracle WebLogic servers to cryptomine. z0Miner is known to exploit Oracle RCE vulnerabilities CVE-2020-14882 and CVE-2020-14883. ASEC provides the attack chain, from exploiting the vulnerabilities to deploy webshells, to using Fast Reverse Proxy (FRP) for Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) communication. Apache ActiveMQ vulnerability CVE-2023-46604 is also exploited. Netcat and AnyDesk are downloaded, and XMrig is used for mining. ASEC provides IOC, Monero Wallet and Mining Pool Address.
🔗 https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/62564/

(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 97.10%

updated 2024-03-08T02:00:01.667000

58 posts

In JetBrains TeamCity before 2023.11.4 authentication bypass allowing to perform admin actions was possible

“Rapid7 throws JetBrains under the bus for 'uncoordinated vulnerability disclosure'
Exploits began within hours of the original disclosure, so patch now”
👇
https://www.theregister.com/2024/03/05/rapid7_jetbrains_vuln_disclosure_dispute/

##
simontsui at 2024-03-05T23:10:54.299Z ##

Computer Weekly takes interest in the JetBrains-Rapid7 feud. "At the core of the disagreement lies a difference in approaches to vulnerability disclosure and patching." They neglected to mention JetBrains's explicitly stating "At this point, we made a decision not to make a coordinated disclosure with Rapid7"
🔗 https://www.computerweekly.com/news/366572453/Rapid7-hits-out-over-botched-vulnerability-disclosure

Shoutout to @todb who was quoted from a 2022 Rapid7 blog post:

With this in mind, said Beardsley, silent patching in fact limits knowledge of the patched vulnerability to skilled exploit developers, that is to say threat actors, so while it is true that silent patching cuts out casual, low-skilled hackers and script kiddies, it also excludes the good guys, legitimate pen testers, the developers of defensive technologies, incident responders, and the entire cyber community who might benefit from being able to understand the issue better and communicate it effectively.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

##
simontsui at 2024-03-05T16:42:41.230Z ##

Why you should care about the new JetBrains TeamCity authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2024-27198 (9.8 critical):

  • On 18 October 2023, Microsoft observed North Korean state-sponsored APTs Diamond Sleet (aka Lazarus Group, publicly attributed to 110 Research Center 3rd Technical Surveillance Bureau of Reconnaissance General Bureau by the US Government) and Onyx Sleet (aka Andariel, also publicly attributed to RGB by the US Government) exploiting a similar JetBrains TeamCity authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2023-42793.
  • On 13 December 2023, CISA published a cybersecurity advisory reporting that the Russian state-sponsored APT29 (Cozy Bear, publicly attributed to Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) by the USG) was mass-exploiting CVE-2023-42793 since September 2023.
  • From public disclosure to proof of concept was 6 days. Exploitation was within 7 days after that (KEV Catalog in 15 days). Nation-state abuse within 12-22 days of public disclosure.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

##
simontsui at 2024-03-05T16:11:10.900Z ##

JetBrains tries to save face by responding to Rapid7's blog post with clarifications. It comes off accusatory and defends their attempt to silently patch. cc: @catc0n @campuscodi @serghei @jgreig
🔗 https://blog.jetbrains.com/teamcity/2024/03/our-approach-addressing-recently-discovered-vulnerabilities-in-teamcity-on-premises/

To reiterate, we never had any intention to release a fix silently without making the full details public. As a CVE Numbering Authority (CNA), we assigned CVE IDs for both issues a day after receiving the report.

We suggested disclosing the details of the vulnerabilities in the same way we have followed in the past (with a time delay between releasing a fix and making a full disclosure), which allows our customers to upgrade their TeamCity instances.

This suggestion was rejected by the Rapid7 team who published full details of the vulnerabilities (and how to exploit them) a few hours after we had released a fix to TeamCity customers.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

##
simontsui at 2024-03-05T13:44:21.638Z ##

@jwarminsky @jgreig ShadowServer is seeing exploitation activity for CVE-2024-27198 since yesterday evening (2200 UTC) with at least 16 IPs scanning. It is likely to be added to CISA's KEV Catalog at this rate.
🔗 https://infosec.exchange/@shadowserver/112042621949812462

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

##
StaceyHolleran at 2024-03-04T19:42:16.187Z ##

Rapid7 has disclosed 2 authentication bypass vulnerabilities, #CVE_2024_27198 and #CVE_2024_27199 affecting JetBrains TeamCity CI/CD server. The most severe of which allows for unauthenticated RCE. https://www.rapid7.com/blog/post/2024/03/04/etr-cve-2024-27198-and-cve-2024-27199-jetbrains-teamcity-multiple-authentication-bypass-vulnerabilities-fixed/

##
simontsui at 2024-03-04T19:33:44.520Z ##

Rapid7 provides technical analyses into JetBrains TeamCity vulnerabilities CVE-2024-27198 and CVE-2024-27199, both of which they consider to be authentication bypasses. They provide what are effectively Proofs of Concept, even if the words "poc" or "proof" aren't used. Rapid7 notes what an indicator of compromise would appear as for CVE-2024-27198. Timeline has an interesting exchange between JetBrains and Rapid7 regarding silent patching.
🔗 https://www.rapid7.com/blog/post/2024/03/04/etr-cve-2024-27198-and-cve-2024-27199-jetbrains-teamcity-multiple-authentication-bypass-vulnerabilities-fixed/

##
decio@infosec.exchange at 2024-03-06T05:39:59.000Z ##

“Rapid7 throws JetBrains under the bus for 'uncoordinated vulnerability disclosure'
Exploits began within hours of the original disclosure, so patch now”
👇
https://www.theregister.com/2024/03/05/rapid7_jetbrains_vuln_disclosure_dispute/

#CyberVeille #jetbrains #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #disclosure

##
simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-03-05T23:10:54.000Z ##

Computer Weekly takes interest in the JetBrains-Rapid7 feud. "At the core of the disagreement lies a difference in approaches to vulnerability disclosure and patching." They neglected to mention JetBrains's explicitly stating "At this point, we made a decision not to make a coordinated disclosure with Rapid7"
🔗 https://www.computerweekly.com/news/366572453/Rapid7-hits-out-over-botched-vulnerability-disclosure

Shoutout to @todb who was quoted from a 2022 Rapid7 blog post:

With this in mind, said Beardsley, silent patching in fact limits knowledge of the patched vulnerability to skilled exploit developers, that is to say threat actors, so while it is true that silent patching cuts out casual, low-skilled hackers and script kiddies, it also excludes the good guys, legitimate pen testers, the developers of defensive technologies, incident responders, and the entire cyber community who might benefit from being able to understand the issue better and communicate it effectively.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

##
simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-03-05T16:42:41.000Z ##

Why you should care about the new JetBrains TeamCity authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2024-27198 (9.8 critical):

  • On 18 October 2023, Microsoft observed North Korean state-sponsored APTs Diamond Sleet (aka Lazarus Group, publicly attributed to 110 Research Center 3rd Technical Surveillance Bureau of Reconnaissance General Bureau by the US Government) and Onyx Sleet (aka Andariel, also publicly attributed to RGB by the US Government) exploiting a similar JetBrains TeamCity authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2023-42793.
  • On 13 December 2023, CISA published a cybersecurity advisory reporting that the Russian state-sponsored APT29 (Cozy Bear, publicly attributed to Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) by the USG) was mass-exploiting CVE-2023-42793 since September 2023.
  • From public disclosure to proof of concept was 6 days. Exploitation was within 7 days after that (KEV Catalog in 15 days). Nation-state abuse within 12-22 days of public disclosure.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

##
simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-03-05T16:11:10.000Z ##

JetBrains tries to save face by responding to Rapid7's blog post with clarifications. It comes off accusatory and defends their attempt to silently patch. cc: @catc0n @campuscodi @serghei @jgreig
🔗 https://blog.jetbrains.com/teamcity/2024/03/our-approach-addressing-recently-discovered-vulnerabilities-in-teamcity-on-premises/

To reiterate, we never had any intention to release a fix silently without making the full details public. As a CVE Numbering Authority (CNA), we assigned CVE IDs for both issues a day after receiving the report.

We suggested disclosing the details of the vulnerabilities in the same way we have followed in the past (with a time delay between releasing a fix and making a full disclosure), which allows our customers to upgrade their TeamCity instances.

This suggestion was rejected by the Rapid7 team who published full details of the vulnerabilities (and how to exploit them) a few hours after we had released a fix to TeamCity customers.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

##
ntkramer at 2024-03-07T21:14:05.450Z ##

Stole this idea from a recent viral thing, but I asked AI to announce JetBrains TeamCity to KEV today in the voice of Moira Rose:

"Darlings, gather round, for I have a tale of digital intrigue and subterfuge most foul. On this day, the cyber sentinels at CISA have unfurled their scrolls to reveal a new entrant upon their illustrious list of Known Exploited Vulnerabilities. The malefactor in question? CVE-2024-27198, a nefarious chink in the armor of JetBrains TeamCity, a bastion of collaborative ingenuity. This particular vulnerability, a sly bypass of authentication, empowers the unscrupulous to don the mantle of an administrator, wielding powers most administrative. Announced with a flourish and a modicum of drama on Monday, the vigilant watchers at GreyNoise have confirmed sightings of this exploit cavorting in the wild, a specter in the digital ether. Let us be on guard, for the digital realm is fraught with shadows and specters, ever lurking, ever waiting to pounce."

##
SophosXOps at 2024-03-07T00:48:51.084Z ##

Meanwhile, Sophos X-Ops’s MDR service and other defensive-security outfits around the industry have seen active attacks, or attack attempts, against multiple customers. So less than 100 hours since the first whisperings of trouble with TeamCity, we’re all in the thick of it. Best get to patching.

https://www.rapid7.com/blog/post/2024/03/04/etr-cve-2024-27198-and-cve-2024-27199-jetbrains-teamcity-multiple-authentication-bypass-vulnerabilities-fixed/

##
SophosXOps at 2024-03-07T00:47:49.081Z ##

The best option is for anyone using the on-prem version of the platform to upgrade immediately to version 2023.11.4 – all versions prior to that are vulnerable. Second-best option is to apply a plug-in patch, which the company’s also made available, until the full upgrade can be done.

https://blog.jetbrains.com/teamcity/2024/03/additional-critical-security-issues-affecting-teamcity-on-premises-cve-2024-27198-and-cve-2024-27199-update-to-2023-11-4-now/
👁️

##
SophosXOps at 2024-03-07T00:47:09.725Z ##

As most security folk are aware, TeamCity pushed out information on these two CVEs over the weekend. Both vulnerabilities are critical-class issues that would allow an attacker – unauthenticated, with merely HTTP(S) access – to bypass auth checks and get administrative control of the TeamCity server. CVE-2024-27198’s authentication bypass weighs in at a robust 9.8 CVSS base score; CVE-2024-27199, a relative path transversal issue, has no CVSS score [ETA: it does now; it's a 7.3, which is high-severity].

https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2024-27198
👁️

##
SophosXOps at 2024-03-07T00:46:23.898Z ##

The situation involving two TeamCity vulnerabilities, CVE-2024-27198 and CVE-2024-27199, continues to unfold. Before noting anything else, we should state that dealing with this should be a highest-priority matter for users of the company’ s on-premises CI/CD dev platform – as in, now.

iagox86 at 2024-03-05T21:01:48.543Z ##

https://www.rapid7.com/blog/post/2024/03/04/etr-cve-2024-27198-and-cve-2024-27199-jetbrains-teamcity-multiple-authentication-bypass-vulnerabilities-fixed/

##
simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-03-04T18:20:23.000Z ##

JetBrains security advisory affecting TeamCity. No mention of exploitation in the wild (yet).

  • CVE-2024-27198 (unknown CVSSv3 score, considered critical severity) Authentication bypass
  • CVE-2024-27198 (unknown CVSSv3 score, considered high severity) Path traversal

🔗 https://blog.jetbrains.com/teamcity/2024/03/additional-critical-security-issues-affecting-teamcity-on-premises-cve-2024-27198-and-cve-2024-27199-update-to-2023-11-4-now/

Why you should care: A TeamCity vulnerability was previously exploited by Russian state-sponsored APT29 as an N-day following public disclosure.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199

zeljkazorz@infosec.exchange at 2024-03-04T16:12:51.000Z ##

JetBrains has fixed two critical security vulnerabilities (CVE-2024-27198, CVE-2024-27199) affecting TeamCity On-Premises and is urging customers to patch them immediately as the release of technical details is imminent.

https://www.helpnetsecurity.com/2024/03/04/cve-2024-27198-cve-2024-27199/

##

CVE-2023-22527
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 96.57%

updated 2024-01-26T17:15:09.290000

2 posts

A template injection vulnerability on older versions of Confluence Data Center and Server allows an unauthenticated attacker to achieve RCE on an affected instance. Customers using an affected version must take immediate action. Most recent supported versions of Confluence Data Center and Server are not affected by this vulnerability as it was ultimately mitigated during regular version updates.

Nuclei template

simontsui at 2024-03-08T13:31:26.687Z ##

VulnCheck explains 3 different Proofs of Concepts for CVE-2023-22527 (10.0 critical, disclosed 16 January 2024 by Atlassian, Confluence RCE) to execute in-memory webshells. They noted that there are pre-existing public exploits that use similar techniques (exploited in the wild). VulnCheck shares detection methods and what indicators of compromise would appear as.
🔗 https://vulncheck.com/blog/confluence-dreams-of-shells

#ProofofConcept #poc #CVE_2023_22527 #threatintel

##
simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-03-08T13:31:26.000Z ##

VulnCheck explains 3 different Proofs of Concepts for CVE-2023-22527 (10.0 critical, disclosed 16 January 2024 by Atlassian, Confluence RCE) to execute in-memory webshells. They noted that there are pre-existing public exploits that use similar techniques (exploited in the wild). VulnCheck shares detection methods and what indicators of compromise would appear as.
🔗 https://vulncheck.com/blog/confluence-dreams-of-shells

#ProofofConcept #poc #CVE_2023_22527 #threatintel

##

CVE-2023-46805
(8.2 HIGH)

EPSS: 96.27%

updated 2024-01-22T17:15:09.080000

14 posts

An authentication bypass vulnerability in the web component of Ivanti ICS 9.x, 22.x and Ivanti Policy Secure allows a remote attacker to access restricted resources by bypassing control checks.

Nuclei template

9 repos

https://github.com/duy-31/CVE-2023-46805_CVE-2024-21887

https://github.com/raminkarimkhani1996/CVE-2023-46805_CVE-2024-21887

https://github.com/mickdec/CVE-2023-46805_CVE-2024-21887_scan_grouped

https://github.com/seajaysec/Ivanti-Connect-Around-Scan

https://github.com/cbeek-r7/CVE-2023-46805

https://github.com/TheRedDevil1/Check-Vulns-Script

https://github.com/w2xim3/CVE-2023-46805

https://github.com/Chocapikk/CVE-2023-46805

https://github.com/yoryio/CVE-2023-46805

simontsui at 2024-03-08T13:41:14.938Z ##

Check Point Research (CPR) reports on a financially motivated threat actor called Magnet Goblin, that leverages "1-day" vulnerabilities in public facing applications. This included Ivanti Connect Secure CVE-2024-21887 within 1 day of Proof of Concept. CPR attributed Magento, Qlink Sense and possibly Apache ActiveMQ campaigns to Magnet Goblin. They also discovered a Linux version of a malware called NerbianRAT, and use of the WARPWIRE JavaScript credential stealer (unknown if there are overlaps with Mandiant's UNC5325 threat actor). Magnet Goblin uses MiniNerbian (a small Linux backdoor) and RMM tools like ScreenConnect and AnyDesk. IOC provided.
🔗 https://research.checkpoint.com/2024/magnet-goblin-targets-publicly-facing-servers-using-1-day-vulnerabilities/

#MagnetGoblin #cybercrime #threatintel #IOC #CVE_2024_21887 #CVE_2022_24086 #CVE_2023_41265 #CVE_2023_41266 #CVE_2023_48365 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_21893 #NerbianRAT #WARPWIRE #MiniNerbian #ScreenConnect #AnyDesk

##
simontsui at 2024-03-02T01:23:46.663Z ##

TechCrunch: NSA confirmed that hackers exploiting flaws in Ivanti’s widely used enterprise VPN appliance have targeted organizations across the U.S. defense sector.
🔗 https://techcrunch.com/2024/03/01/nsa-says-its-tracking-ivanti-cyberattacks-as-hackers-hit-us-defense-sector/

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_22024 #CISA #securityadvisory

##
0xThiebaut at 2024-03-01T14:51:22.738Z ##

We're still discovering further ramifications to #Ivanti's #PulseSecure vulnerabilities (#CVE_2023_46805 & #CVE_2024_21887). In February, we identified two new backdoors: #SparkCockpit & #SparkTar. Both backdoors employ selective interception of TLS communication, offer multiple degrees of persistence and access possibilities into the victim network (e.g., traffic tunneling through SOCKS proxy).

👀 Analysis & detection rules at https://blog.nviso.eu/2024/03/01/covert-tls-n-day-backdoors-sparkcockpit-sparktar/

The findings of our investigation have been independently corroborated by the research performed by Mandiant and have partially been observed by Fortinet.

#threatintel #forensics #reverseengineering

##
simontsui at 2024-02-29T18:13:43.608Z ##

Hot off the press! CISA along with FBI, MS-ISAC, Australia ASD ACSC, NCSC-UK, NCSC-NZ, Canadian Centre for Cyber Security and CERT NZ release joint cybersecurity advisory Threat Actors Exploit Multiple Vulnerabilities in Ivanti Connect Secure and Policy Secure Gateways. It includes TTPs, IOCs, and detection methods to help network defenders mitigate risk.
🔗 https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-060b

Of particular concern, the authoring organizations and industry partners have determined that cyber threat actors are able to deceive Ivanti’s internal and external Integrity Checker Tool (ICT), resulting in a failure to detect compromise.

During multiple incident response engagements associated with this activity, CISA identified that Ivanti’s internal and previous external ICT failed to detect compromise. In addition, CISA has conducted independent research in a lab environment validating that the Ivanti ICT is not sufficient to detect compromise and that a cyber threat actor may be able to gain root-level persistence despite issuing factory resets.

The authoring organizations strongly urge all organizations to consider the significant risk of adversary access to, and persistence on, Ivanti Connect Secure and Ivanti Policy Secure gateways when determining whether to continue operating these devices in an enterprise environment.

cc: @campuscodi @briankrebs @deepthoughts10 @serghei @selenalarson @DaveMWilburn

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_22024 #CISA #securityadvisory

##
simontsui at 2024-02-28T21:15:54.019Z ##

This line from Mandiant's article stuck out to me: "In addition, we have seen the threat actor demonstrate a nuanced understanding of the appliance and their ability to subvert detection throughout this campaign."

The reason is because of the following:

The internal ICT is configured to run in two-hour intervals by default and is meant to be run in conjunction with continuous monitoring. Any malicious file system modifications made and reverted between the two-hour scan intervals would remain undetected by the ICT. When the activation and deactivation routines are performed tactfully in quick succession, it can minimize the risk of ICT detection by timing the activation routine to coincide precisely with the intended use of the BUSHWALK webshell.

This sentence also concerns me, giving me flashbacks to Eclypsium's article

An encrypted version of BUSHWALK is placed in a directory excluded by the integrity checker tool (ICT)

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_22024

##
simontsui at 2024-02-27T19:45:07.447Z ##

Ivanti has a related blog post regarding evolving threat actor tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs). These findings were identified in the ongoing analysis of the previously disclosed vulnerabilities affecting Ivanti Connect Secure, Policy Secure and ZTA gateways, and include potential persistence techniques.
🔗 https://www.ivanti.com/blog/enhanced-external-integrity-checking-tool-to-provide-additional-visibility-and-protection-for-customers-against-evolving-threat-actor-techniques-in-relation-to-previously-disclosed-vulnerabilities

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_21893 #CVE_2024_22024

🔗 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/blog/investigating-ivanti-exploitation-persistence

cc: @campuscodi @iagox86 @brett

##

CVE-2024-21893
(8.2 HIGH)

EPSS: 96.25%

updated 2024-02-01T02:00:01.187000

6 posts

A server-side request forgery vulnerability in the SAML component of Ivanti Connect Secure (9.x, 22.x) and Ivanti Policy Secure (9.x, 22.x) and Ivanti Neurons for ZTA allows an attacker to access certain restricted resources without authentication.

Nuclei template

4 repos

https://github.com/gobysec/GobyVuls

https://github.com/gobysec/Goby

https://github.com/h4x0r-dz/CVE-2024-21893.py

https://github.com/Chocapikk/CVE-2024-21893-to-CVE-2024-21887

simontsui at 2024-03-08T13:41:14.938Z ##

Check Point Research (CPR) reports on a financially motivated threat actor called Magnet Goblin, that leverages "1-day" vulnerabilities in public facing applications. This included Ivanti Connect Secure CVE-2024-21887 within 1 day of Proof of Concept. CPR attributed Magento, Qlink Sense and possibly Apache ActiveMQ campaigns to Magnet Goblin. They also discovered a Linux version of a malware called NerbianRAT, and use of the WARPWIRE JavaScript credential stealer (unknown if there are overlaps with Mandiant's UNC5325 threat actor). Magnet Goblin uses MiniNerbian (a small Linux backdoor) and RMM tools like ScreenConnect and AnyDesk. IOC provided.

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_21893 #CVE_2024_22024

##
decio at 2024-02-28T09:19:35.550Z ##

la suite des investigations de Mndiant sur l'exploitation à grande échelle des failles zero-day d'Ivanti par des acteurs de menaces liés à la Chine, visant notamment le secteur industriel de la défense américain

("demonstrate a nuanced understanding" is my new mantra)

Les tentatives d'exploitation massives et le développement d'un exploit de contournement des mesures de mitigation pour CVE-2024-21893 par UNC5325 ont été observés. Malgré des tentatives pour maintenir la persistance à travers des mises à jour et réinitialisations système, les attaquants n'ont pas réussi en raison de défauts dans le code malveillant. Ivanti a publié un nouvel outil de vérification d'intégrité externe et mis à jour son guide de remédiation.

ça sent l'opération annexe de "cool down"
⬇️​
(IoCs et YARA rule inside)

"Cutting Edge, Part 3: Investigating Ivanti Connect Secure VPN Exploitation and Persistence Attempts"
👇​
https://www.mandiant.com/resources/blog/investigating-ivanti-exploitation-persistence

#CyberVeille #Ivanti

##
decio@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-28T09:19:35.000Z ##

la suite des investigations de Mndiant sur l'exploitation à grande échelle des failles zero-day d'Ivanti par des acteurs de menaces liés à la Chine, visant notamment le secteur industriel de la défense américain

("demonstrate a nuanced understanding" is my new mantra)

Les tentatives d'exploitation massives et le développement d'un exploit de contournement des mesures de mitigation pour CVE-2024-21893 par UNC5325 ont été observés. Malgré des tentatives pour maintenir la persistance à travers des mises à jour et réinitialisations système, les attaquants n'ont pas réussi en raison de défauts dans le code malveillant. Ivanti a publié un nouvel outil de vérification d'intégrité externe et mis à jour son guide de remédiation.

ça sent l'opération annexe de "cool down"
⬇️​
(IoCs et YARA rule inside)

"Cutting Edge, Part 3: Investigating Ivanti Connect Secure VPN Exploitation and Persistence Attempts"
👇​
https://www.mandiant.com/resources/blog/investigating-ivanti-exploitation-persistence

#CyberVeille #Ivanti

##

CVE-2024-1709
(10.0 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 93.46%

updated 2024-02-23T02:00:01.867000

13 posts

ConnectWise ScreenConnect 23.9.7 and prior are affected by an Authentication Bypass Using an Alternate Path or Channel vulnerability, which may allow an attacker direct access to confidential information or critical systems.

Nuclei template

2 repos

https://github.com/W01fh4cker/ScreenConnect-AuthBypass-RCE

https://github.com/HussainFathy/CVE-2024-1709

H3liumb0y at 2024-03-05T09:16:48.983Z ##

"🚨 ScreenConnect Exploits Unleash ToddleShark Malware by Kimsuky 🚨"

Kimsuky, the North Korean APT, leverages vulnerabilities in ScreenConnect (CVE-2024-1708 & CVE-2024-1709) to deploy ToddleShark, aiming at espionage. This polymorphic malware uses Microsoft binaries for stealth and conducts extensive data theft. It's an evolution of Kimsuky's espionage toolkit, hinting at their refined strategies for long-term intelligence gathering. ToddleShark manipulates registry settings, employs scheduled tasks for persistence, and exfiltrates data using PEM certificates, showcasing advanced obfuscation and evasion techniques. Be vigilant and patch up!

#CyberSecurity #APT #NorthKorea #Malware #ScreenConnect #CVE2024_1708 #CVE2024_1709 #ToddleShark #Kimsuky #DataTheft #Espionage #InfoSec

Source: BleepingComputer.com

Mitre - Kimsuky

##

##
pentesttools at 2024-02-28T12:55:44.075Z ##

🚨 Just launched: FREE scanner for #SlashAndGrab 🥷, the ConnectWise ScreenConnect vulnerabilities: https://pentest-tools.com/network-vulnerability-scanning/connectwise-screenconnect-cve-2024-1709-vulnerability-scanner

👇 Here are the specs:

When John Hammond started posting about CVE-2024-1709 (CVSSv3 10) & CVE-2024-1708 (CVSSv3 8.4), we instantly picked up on them.

Our team moved fast and added detection for both CVEs, knowing attackers are actively trying to use them (CVE-2024-1709 especially) to bypass security controls and gain unrestricted system access.

We also turned it into a FREE tool for any pentester to use: https://pentest-tools.com/network-vulnerability-scanning/connectwise-screenconnect-cve-2024-1709-vulnerability-scanner

##
todb at 2024-02-28T03:12:55.239Z ##

@austinlarsen @simontsui nbd, you're not the only one.

I'm still on the (now somewhat passive) hunt for any real evidence of exploitation for the other one. Lots of conjecture, loads of hits for CVE-2024-1709, but nothing solid for CVE-2024-1708. Every news outlet seems to just conflate the two and sometimes gets them backwards.

##
simontsui at 2024-02-27T12:45:28.527Z ##

@campuscodi one question I have is, do they even need to exploit CVE-2024-1708? With CVE-2024-1709, they create an admin user on the ScreenConnect server, giving them full control. This is a one character cheat, whereas 1708 requires user interaction and privileges (CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:H/UI:R/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H)

I don't specifically see it in the Trend Micro article, but is there actual evidence of CVE-2024-1708 exploitation? Since unpatched versions of ScreenConnect are vulnerable to both 1708 and 1709, it's almost certainly going to make 1709 the more valuable exploit.

##
campuscodi@mastodon.social at 2024-02-27T12:34:44.000Z ##

Trend Micro says the BlackBasta and the Bl00dy ransomware gangs are now exploiting two recently disclosed ScreenConnect vulnerabilities (CVE-2024-1708 and CVE-2024-1709) to breach networks and encrypt files.

https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/24/b/threat-actor-groups-including-black-basta-are-exploiting-recent-.html

CVE-2023-41265
(9.9 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 92.32%

updated 2023-09-08T13:59:58.123000

2 posts

An HTTP Request Tunneling vulnerability found in Qlik Sense Enterprise for Windows for versions May 2023 Patch 3 and earlier, February 2023 Patch 7 and earlier, November 2022 Patch 10 and earlier, and August 2022 Patch 12 and earlier allows a remote attacker to elevate their privilege by tunneling HTTP requests in the raw HTTP request. This allows them to send requests that get executed by the bac

1 repos

#search_error

simontsui at 2024-03-08T13:41:14.938Z ##

Check Point Research (CPR) reports on a financially motivated threat actor called Magnet Goblin, that leverages "1-day" vulnerabilities in public facing applications. This included Ivanti Connect Secure CVE-2024-21887 within 1 day of Proof of Concept. CPR attributed Magento, Qlink Sense and possibly Apache ActiveMQ campaigns to Magnet Goblin. They also discovered a Linux version of a malware called NerbianRAT, and use of the WARPWIRE JavaScript credential stealer (unknown if there are overlaps with Mandiant's UNC5325 threat actor). Magnet Goblin uses MiniNerbian (a small Linux backdoor) and RMM tools like ScreenConnect and AnyDesk. IOC provided.
🔗 https://research.checkpoint.com/2024/magnet-goblin-targets-publicly-facing-servers-using-1-day-vulnerabilities/

#MagnetGoblin #cybercrime #threatintel #IOC #CVE_2024_21887 #CVE_2022_24086 #CVE_2023_41265 #CVE_2023_41266 #CVE_2023_48365 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_21893 #NerbianRAT #WARPWIRE #MiniNerbian #ScreenConnect #AnyDesk

##

simontsui at 2024-02-27T17:55:58.590Z ##

@campuscodi Important to note that APT28 exploited CVE-2023-23397 as a zero-day since early 2022.

CVE-2023-23397 is a Microsoft Outlook Elevation of Privilege Vulnerability (9.8 critical, disclosed 14 March 2023 on Patch Tuesday as exploited zero day, added to CISA KEV Catalog same day).

simontsui at 2024-03-08T13:41:14.938Z ##

Check Point Research (CPR) reports on a financially motivated threat actor called Magnet Goblin, that leverages "1-day" vulnerabilities in public facing applications. This included Ivanti Connect Secure CVE-2024-21887 within 1 day of Proof of Concept. CPR attributed Magento, Qlink Sense and possibly Apache ActiveMQ campaigns to Magnet Goblin. They also discovered a Linux version of a malware called NerbianRAT, and use of the WARPWIRE JavaScript credential stealer (unknown if there are overlaps with Mandiant's UNC5325 threat actor). Magnet Goblin uses MiniNerbian (a small Linux backdoor) and RMM tools like ScreenConnect and AnyDesk. IOC provided.

CVE-2024-23897
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 38.41%

updated 2024-03-07T17:47:35.020000

1 posts

Jenkins 2.441 and earlier, LTS 2.426.2 and earlier does not disable a feature of its CLI command parser that replaces an '@' character followed by a file path in an argument with the file's contents, allowing unauthenticated attackers to read arbitrary files on the Jenkins controller file system.

simontsui at 2024-02-27T15:35:00.614Z ##

Analyst comment: It's a little concerning how there's no reporting of active exploitation of CVE-2024-23897 (7.5 high, disclosed 24 January 2024 by Jenkins) an arbitrary file read vulnerability leading to remote code execution. It already has multiple proofs of concept. And yet the only report was a single exploitation in a honeypot capture by a university graduate student, which everyone repeated ad nauseam: https://infosec.exchange/@simontsui/111835020715820485

(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 28.87%

updated 2022-02-22T17:40:45.277000

4 posts

Adobe Commerce versions 2.4.3-p1 (and earlier) and 2.3.7-p2 (and earlier) are affected by an improper input validation vulnerability during the checkout process. Exploitation of this issue does not require user interaction and could result in arbitrary code execution.

simontsui at 2024-03-08T13:41:14.938Z ##

Check Point Research (CPR) reports on a financially motivated threat actor called Magnet Goblin, that leverages "1-day" vulnerabilities in public facing applications. This included Ivanti Connect Secure CVE-2024-21887 within 1 day of Proof of Concept. CPR attributed Magento, Qlink Sense and possibly Apache ActiveMQ campaigns to Magnet Goblin. They also discovered a Linux version of a malware called NerbianRAT, and use of the WARPWIRE JavaScript credential stealer (unknown if there are overlaps with Mandiant's UNC5325 threat actor). Magnet Goblin uses MiniNerbian (a small Linux backdoor) and RMM tools like ScreenConnect and AnyDesk. IOC provided.
🔗 https://research.checkpoint.com/2024/magnet-goblin-targets-publicly-facing-servers-using-1-day-vulnerabilities/

##
simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-03-08T13:41:14.000Z ##

Check Point Research (CPR) reports on a financially motivated threat actor called Magnet Goblin, that leverages "1-day" vulnerabilities in public facing applications. This included Ivanti Connect Secure CVE-2024-21887 within 1 day of Proof of Concept. CPR attributed Magento, Qlink Sense and possibly Apache ActiveMQ campaigns to Magnet Goblin. They also discovered a Linux version of a malware called NerbianRAT, and use of the WARPWIRE JavaScript credential stealer (unknown if there are overlaps with Mandiant's UNC5325 threat actor). Magnet Goblin uses MiniNerbian (a small Linux backdoor) and RMM tools like ScreenConnect and AnyDesk. IOC provided.
🔗 https://research.checkpoint.com/2024/magnet-goblin-targets-publicly-facing-servers-using-1-day-vulnerabilities/

#MagnetGoblin #cybercrime #threatintel #IOC #CVE_2024_21887 #CVE_2022_24086 #CVE_2023_41265 #CVE_2023_41266 #CVE_2023_48365 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_21893 #NerbianRAT #WARPWIRE #MiniNerbian #ScreenConnect #AnyDesk

##

CVE-2023-6448
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 6.84%

updated 2023-12-19T14:15:07.183000

4 posts

Unitronics VisiLogic before version 9.9.00, used in Vision and Samba PLCs and HMIs, uses a default administrative password. An unauthenticated attacker with network access can take administrative control of a vulnerable system.

mmguero at 2024-03-06T17:35:25.298Z ##

It is with great relish that we announce the v24.03.0 release of Malcolm, a powerful, easily deployable network traffic analysis tool suite.

Although the previous Malcolm release came out just a few weeks ago, the Malcolm development team felt there was enough new goodness to cut an early March release. This release contains new features, bug fixes and component version updates, including:

  • Support for JSON-delimited Zeek log ingestion (issue #65)
    • JSON format logs generated by Zeek instances external to Malcolm can now be ingested by Malcolm, either by forwarding them with a tool like filebeat or Fluent Bit or by uploading an archive file containing the log files. While Malcolm still generates TSV-formatted Zeek logs internally by default, it can be configured to create JSON format Zeek logs as well.
  • Created new dashboards for other non-network and third-party log data (issue #414)
    • While Malcolm's main focus is analyzing network traffic log metadata (generated by Zeek, Arkime, and Suricata), it can also receive and index logs from other sources, such as:
      • System resource utilization metrics (CPU, memory, disk, network, etc.)
      • System temperatures
      • Linux system logs
      • Windows event logs
      • Process or service health status
      • Logs appended to textual log files (e.g., tail-ing a log file)
      • The output of an external script or program
      • Messages in the form of MQTT control packets
      • many more…
    • This release revamped some existing dashboards and added several new ones to visualize some of these common third-party and host logs.
  • Container security review (issue #236)
    • Malcolm's container images are automatically scanned by Trivy as they are build as part of our CI workflows. This release entailed an in-depth review of the results from the latest scans which resulted in resolving most of the outstanding issues found.
  • Support /attributes and /events enpoints from MISP feed for Zeek intel generation (issue #336)
    • This release expands Malcolm's ability to pull from MISP feeds to generate Zeek intel files. When Malcolm connects to user-provided URLs for the MISP feeds, it will attempt to determine the format of the data served and process it accordingly. This could be presented as:
      • a manifest JSON file
      • a directory listing containing a file named manifest.json
      • a directory listing of JSON files without a manifest.json file
      • a list of Events returned for a request via the MISP Automation API made to a MISP platform's /events endpoint
      • a list of Attributes returned for a request via the MISP Automation API made to a MISP platform's /attributes endpoint
    • In addition to MISP, STIX™ v2.0/v2.1 indicators and TAXII™ 2.0/2.1 feeds are supported as well.
  • Added Suricata rules to detect Unitronics VisiLogic CVE-2023-6448 (issue #394) from the DHS CISA Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog
  • Minor tweaks to the new Malcolm landing page (issue #427)
  • Incorporated a new ICSNPP Profinet IO CM network protocol analyzer (issue #429)
  • Version updates to some major Malcolm components:
    • Arkime to v5.0.1
    • OpenSearch and OpenSearch Dashboards to v2.12.0
  • A handful of bug fixes:
    • fixed the way we handle false values in environment variables in local.zeek (issue #413)
    • addressed a few issues with the install.py script when installing from downloaeded GitHub release artifacts (issue #416)
    • fixed a condition in which the htadmin was creating htpasswd file entries without a newline between them (issue #426)
    • removed a hard-coded date value in Arkime-to-Kibana pivot links (issue #428)
    • corrected unencrypted, unzipped extracted file download not working in the extracted files interface (issue #431)
    • a few fixes to the Raspberry Pi 4 build of Hedgehog Linux

Keep your eyes open, because there's lots more on the way in the coming months, including a bunch of end-user training topics for which we hope to develop training/documentation/videos. If you've got suggestions, we want to hear them.

Malcolm and Hedgehog Linux may be obtained by pulling or building the Docker images and/or building the ISO installer images as described in the documentation. Unofficial ISO installer images for Malcolm and Hedgehog Linux are not hosted on GitHub, but may be downloaded from https://malcolm.fyi/.

#Malcolm #HedgehogLinux #Zeek #Arkime #NetBox #OpenSearch #Elasticsearch #Suricata #PCAP #NetworkTrafficAnalysis #networksecuritymonitoring #OT #ICS #icssecurity #CyberSecurity #Cyber #Infosec #GitHub #INL #DHS #CISA #CISAgov #Kubernetes #Docker #raspberrypi

simontsui at 2024-02-27T18:49:09.054Z ##

@mttaggart remember that time the civilian government agency CISA assigned a CVE ID for a default password vulnerability (CVE-2023-6448 for reference) and put it into the KEV Catalog? #CVECrowdDeny

##
mmguero@infosec.exchange at 2024-03-06T17:35:25.000Z ##

It is with great relish that we announce the v24.03.0 release of Malcolm, a powerful, easily deployable network traffic analysis tool suite.

Although the previous Malcolm release came out just a few weeks ago, the Malcolm development team felt there was enough new goodness to cut an early March release. This release contains new features, bug fixes and component version updates, including:

  • Support for JSON-delimited Zeek log ingestion (issue #65)
    • JSON format logs generated by Zeek instances external to Malcolm can now be ingested by Malcolm, either by forwarding them with a tool like filebeat or Fluent Bit or by uploading an archive file containing the log files. While Malcolm still generates TSV-formatted Zeek logs internally by default, it can be configured to create JSON format Zeek logs as well.
  • Created new dashboards for other non-network and third-party log data (issue #414)
    • While Malcolm's main focus is analyzing network traffic log metadata (generated by Zeek, Arkime, and Suricata), it can also receive and index logs from other sources, such as:
      • System resource utilization metrics (CPU, memory, disk, network, etc.)
      • System temperatures
      • Linux system logs
      • Windows event logs
      • Process or service health status
      • Logs appended to textual log files (e.g., tail-ing a log file)
      • The output of an external script or program
      • Messages in the form of MQTT control packets
      • many more…
    • This release revamped some existing dashboards and added several new ones to visualize some of these common third-party and host logs.
  • Container security review (issue #236)
    • Malcolm's container images are automatically scanned by Trivy as they are build as part of our CI workflows. This release entailed an in-depth review of the results from the latest scans which resulted in resolving most of the outstanding issues found.
  • Support /attributes and /events enpoints from MISP feed for Zeek intel generation (issue #336)
    • This release expands Malcolm's ability to pull from MISP feeds to generate Zeek intel files. When Malcolm connects to user-provided URLs for the MISP feeds, it will attempt to determine the format of the data served and process it accordingly. This could be presented as:
      • a manifest JSON file
      • a directory listing containing a file named manifest.json
      • a directory listing of JSON files without a manifest.json file
      • a list of Events returned for a request via the MISP Automation API made to a MISP platform's /events endpoint
      • a list of Attributes returned for a request via the MISP Automation API made to a MISP platform's /attributes endpoint
    • In addition to MISP, STIX™ v2.0/v2.1 indicators and TAXII™ 2.0/2.1 feeds are supported as well.
  • Added Suricata rules to detect Unitronics VisiLogic CVE-2023-6448 (issue #394) from the DHS CISA Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog
  • Minor tweaks to the new Malcolm landing page (issue #427)
  • Incorporated a new ICSNPP Profinet IO CM network protocol analyzer (issue #429)
  • Version updates to some major Malcolm components:
    • Arkime to v5.0.1
    • OpenSearch and OpenSearch Dashboards to v2.12.0
  • A handful of bug fixes:
    • fixed the way we handle false values in environment variables in local.zeek (issue #413)
    • addressed a few issues with the install.py script when installing from downloaeded GitHub release artifacts (issue #416)
    • fixed a condition in which the htadmin was creating htpasswd file entries without a newline between them (issue #426)
    • removed a hard-coded date value in Arkime-to-Kibana pivot links (issue #428)
    • corrected unencrypted, unzipped extracted file download not working in the extracted files interface (issue #431)
    • a few fixes to the Raspberry Pi 4 build of Hedgehog Linux

Keep your eyes open, because there's lots more on the way in the coming months, including a bunch of end-user training topics for which we hope to develop training/documentation/videos. If you've got suggestions, we want to hear them.

Malcolm and Hedgehog Linux may be obtained by pulling or building the Docker images and/or building the ISO installer images as described in the documentation. Unofficial ISO installer images for Malcolm and Hedgehog Linux are not hosted on GitHub, but may be downloaded from https://malcolm.fyi/.

#Malcolm #HedgehogLinux #Zeek #Arkime #NetBox #OpenSearch #Elasticsearch #Suricata #PCAP #NetworkTrafficAnalysis #networksecuritymonitoring #OT #ICS #icssecurity #CyberSecurity #Cyber #Infosec #GitHub #INL #DHS #CISA #CISAgov #Kubernetes #Docker #raspberrypi

CVE-2024-21626
(8.6 HIGH)

EPSS: 5.06%

updated 2024-02-19T03:15:08.413000

4 posts

runc is a CLI tool for spawning and running containers on Linux according to the OCI specification. In runc 1.1.11 and earlier, due to an internal file descriptor leak, an attacker could cause a newly-spawned container process (from runc exec) to have a working directory in the host filesystem namespace, allowing for a container escape by giving access to the host filesystem ("attack 2"). The same

https://github.com/Wall1e/CVE-2024-21626-POC

https://github.com/NitroCao/CVE-2024-21626

https://github.com/abian2/CVE-2024-21626

simontsui at 2024-02-28T23:00:36.861Z ##

unexpected Microsoft Security Response Center (MSRC) security advisory: GitHub: CVE-2024-21626 (8.6 high, known as #LeakyVessels) Container breakout through process.cwd trickery and leaked fds. "CVE-2024-21626 involves a file descriptor leak in runc, potentially enabling attackers to access the host system."

CVE-2024-21410
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 2.32%

updated 2024-02-26T21:10:38.713000

2 posts

Microsoft Exchange Server Elevation of Privilege Vulnerability

1 repos

https://github.com/FreakyM0ndy/CVE-2024-21410-poc

simontsui at 2024-03-05T00:07:57.678Z ##

Increased scrutiny on Microsoft as @dangoodin writes for Ars Technica: Hackers exploited Windows 0-day for 6 months after Microsoft knew of it. Microsoft only announced two exploited zero-days during their February 2024 Patch Tuesday, but botched an update to a third exploited zero-day CVE-2024-21410 (accidentally updating CVE-2024-21413 instead). Now, Avast claimed that CVE-2024-21338 was exploited in the wild since at least August 2023 (date that they notified Microsoft with a PoC).

#CISA #KEV #CVE_2024_21338 #vulnerability #IOCTL #EoP #Avast #eitw #activeexploitation #MSRC #Microsoft

simontsui at 2024-03-08T19:53:17.235Z ##

@h0wdy of GreyNoise details the process of discovering CVE-2024-21762 (9.6 critical, disclosed 08 February 2024 by Fortinet as an exploited zero-day), a non-disclosed out-of-bounds write vulnerability in Fortinet FortiOS and FortiProxy. The blog post transitions from getting the software, to patch diffing, to developing a detection.
🔗 https://www.labs.greynoise.io/grimoire/2024-03-08-fortinet-cve-2024-21762/

Analyst note: While the FortiGuard PSIRT advisory wrote "Note: This is potentially being exploited in the wild", Fortinet contacted CISA earlier to say "definitely" exploited. Hence the CISA KEV entry within 24 hours of public disclosure.

#GreyNoise #CVE_2024_21762 #Fortinet #FortiOS #vulnerability #eitw

##

CVE-2007-4559
(0 None)

EPSS: 1.34%

updated 2023-09-17T09:15:07.747000

1 posts

Directory traversal vulnerability in the (1) extract and (2) extractall functions in the tarfile module in Python allows user-assisted remote attackers to overwrite arbitrary files via a .. (dot dot) sequence in filenames in a TAR archive, a related issue to CVE-2001-1267.

3 repos

https://github.com/davidholiday/CVE-2007-4559

https://github.com/Ooscaar/MALW

https://github.com/advanced-threat-research/Creosote

mr_daemon@untrusted.website at 2024-03-08T23:13:33.000Z ##

@maxgot The module has a nice directory traversal CVE (CVE-2007-4559) going for it, and the direct fix is unfortunately intrusive, and has been backported to older python runtimes -- hence the minor.

If you're going to extract untrusted tarballs you should probably be more specific with the filter, but otherwise the soft check for it is basically just `if hasattr(tarfile, 'data_filter')`, which isn't too bad. You can fall back to the older behavior with a fat warning to update Python.

##

CVE-2020-3566
(7.5 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.33%

updated 2023-01-27T05:02:05

4 posts

A vulnerability in the Distance Vector Multicast Routing Protocol (DVMRP) feature of Cisco IOS XR Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to exhaust process memory of an affected device. The vulnerability is due to insufficient queue management for Internet Group Management Protocol (IGMP) packets. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending crafted IGMP traffic to an

1 repos

https://github.com/n0npax/CVE-2020-35669

H3liumb0y at 2024-03-08T09:23:34.736Z ##

#Cisco released patches for two high-severity vulnerabilities in its IOS XR software, #CVE20203566 and #CVE20203569, that were being exploited in the wild. These vulnerabilities, found in the software's Distance Vector Multicast Routing Protocol ( #DVMRP) feature, could allow unauthenticated attackers to send specially crafted #IGMP packets (packets used for managing the membership of Internet Protocol multicast groups.), leading to a crash or memory exhaustion on affected devices. Cisco provided mitigations and has now issued Software Maintenance Upgrades to fully address these vulnerabilities​​.

Cisco IOS XR is a network operating system designed by Cisco Systems for their high-end carrier-grade routers that are part of the CRS series, ASR 9000, and XR12000. IOS XR aims to provide more stability and features necessary for today's ISPs and large enterprise IT networks, with an emphasis on modularity and a fully distributed forwarding plane for enhanced performance. It supports a wide range of routing protocols and features aimed at maintaining continuous system operation and improved network reliability.

Cisco Issues Patch for High-Severity VPN Hijacking Bug in Secure Client

##
H3liumb0y@infosec.exchange at 2024-03-08T09:23:34.000Z ##

#Cisco released patches for two high-severity vulnerabilities in its IOS XR software, #CVE20203566 and #CVE20203569, that were being exploited in the wild. These vulnerabilities, found in the software's Distance Vector Multicast Routing Protocol ( #DVMRP) feature, could allow unauthenticated attackers to send specially crafted #IGMP packets (packets used for managing the membership of Internet Protocol multicast groups.), leading to a crash or memory exhaustion on affected devices. Cisco provided mitigations and has now issued Software Maintenance Upgrades to fully address these vulnerabilities​​.

Cisco IOS XR is a network operating system designed by Cisco Systems for their high-end carrier-grade routers that are part of the CRS series, ASR 9000, and XR12000. IOS XR aims to provide more stability and features necessary for today's ISPs and large enterprise IT networks, with an emphasis on modularity and a fully distributed forwarding plane for enhanced performance. It supports a wide range of routing protocols and features aimed at maintaining continuous system operation and improved network reliability.

CVE-2020-3569
(7.5 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.33%

updated 2023-01-29T05:03:08

4 posts

Multiple vulnerabilities in the Distance Vector Multicast Routing Protocol (DVMRP) feature of Cisco IOS XR Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to either immediately crash the Internet Group Management Protocol (IGMP) process or make it consume available memory and eventually crash. The memory consumption may negatively impact other processes that are running on the device. The

##

CVE-2020-15778
(7.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.29%

updated 2023-11-07T03:17:54.963000

2 posts

scp in OpenSSH through 8.3p1 allows command injection in the scp.c toremote function, as demonstrated by backtick characters in the destination argument. NOTE: the vendor reportedly has stated that they intentionally omit validation of "anomalous argument transfers" because that could "stand a great chance of breaking existing workflows."

3 repos

https://github.com/cpandya2909/CVE-2020-15778

https://github.com/Evan-Zhangyf/CVE-2020-15778

https://github.com/Neko-chanQwQ/CVE-2020-15778-Exploit

scottwilson at 2024-03-06T21:09:37.702Z ##

CVE-2020-15778 was published a few years ago, to document a remote code injection issue in the scp binary (part of OpenSSH 8.3p1 and older). The CVE has been updated a few times over the years. Red Hat has been making updates to OpenSSH and as part of that process uncovered a few additional vulnerabilities (CVE-2018-2068, CVE-2019-6111).

Red Hat and other vendors are recommending the use of rsync with SSH instead of scp, because the issues are not going to be fixed due to the patches breaking several uses cases. These issues are being detected by popular vulnerability scanning platforms as Nessus Plugin ID 159492 and Qualys QID 105936.

TL;DR – Stop using scp and start using rsync with SSH.

Command syntax to help you:

OLD – scp file user@host:/path/to/remote/file.txt
NEW – rsync -av -e ssh file user@host:/path/to/file.txt

(the -e ssh option instructs rsync to connect to a remote system over SSH).

#scp #rsync #linux #infosec #cybersecurity #vulnerability

References:
https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2020-15778
https://access.redhat.com/articles/5284081
https://www.tenable.com/plugins/nessus/159492
https://success.qualys.com/discussions/s/question/0D52L00005S49GjSAJ/how-to-solve-openssh-command-injection-vulnerability-qid105936-vulnerability

##
scottwilson@infosec.exchange at 2024-03-06T21:09:37.000Z ##

##

CVE-2019-6111
(5.9 MEDIUM)

EPSS: 0.20%

updated 2023-11-07T03:13:05.610000

2 posts

An issue was discovered in OpenSSH 7.9. Due to the scp implementation being derived from 1983 rcp, the server chooses which files/directories are sent to the client. However, the scp client only performs cursory validation of the object name returned (only directory traversal attacks are prevented). A malicious scp server (or Man-in-The-Middle attacker) can overwrite arbitrary files in the scp cli

2 repos

https://github.com/AntonVanAssche/CSV-NPE2223

https://github.com/53n7hu/SNP

scottwilson at 2024-03-06T21:09:37.702Z ##

CVE-2020-15778 was published a few years ago, to document a remote code injection issue in the scp binary (part of OpenSSH 8.3p1 and older). The CVE has been updated a few times over the years. Red Hat has been making updates to OpenSSH and as part of that process uncovered a few additional vulnerabilities (CVE-2018-2068, CVE-2019-6111).

Red Hat and other vendors are recommending the use of rsync with SSH instead of scp, because the issues are not going to be fixed due to the patches breaking several uses cases. These issues are being detected by popular vulnerability scanning platforms as Nessus Plugin ID 159492 and Qualys QID 105936.

TL;DR – Stop using scp and start using rsync with SSH.

Command syntax to help you:

OLD – scp file user@host:/path/to/remote/file.txt
NEW – rsync -av -e ssh file user@host:/path/to/file.txt

(the -e ssh option instructs rsync to connect to a remote system over SSH).

CVE-2023-21237
(5.5 MEDIUM)

EPSS: 0.18%

updated 2024-03-06T02:00:02.080000

4 posts

In applyRemoteView of NotificationContentInflater.java, there is a possible way to hide foreground service notification due to misleading or insufficient UI. This could lead to local information disclosure with no additional execution privileges needed. User interaction is not needed for exploitation.Product: AndroidVersions: Android-13Android ID: A-251586912

simontsui at 2024-03-05T18:47:57.860Z ##

In tracking the origins of exploitation leading up to their KEV Catalog additions:

  • I previously informed the CISA Vulnerability Management Team of potential exploitation of CVE-2021-36380 as part of an IZ1H9 Mirai-based DDoS campaign reported by Fortinet on 09 October 2023. What they do with that information is up to them.
  • The Pixel Update Bulletin published 13 June 2023 included an announcement that read "Note: There are indications that CVE-2023-21237 may be under limited, targeted exploitation."

#CISA #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #eitw #activeexploitation #vulnerability #CVE_2023_21237 #CVE_2021_36380

##
simontsui at 2024-03-05T16:07:00.301Z ##

Hot off the press! CISA adds 2 vulnerabilities to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog.
🔗 https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2024/03/05/cisa-adds-two-known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog

  • CVE-2023-21237 (5.5 medium) Android Pixel Information Disclosure Vulnerability
  • CVE-2021-36380 (9.8 critical) Sunhillo SureLine OS Command Injection Vulnerablity

CVE-2024-23296
(7.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.17%

updated 2024-03-07T19:15:11.687000

21 posts

A memory corruption issue was addressed with improved validation. This issue is fixed in iOS 17.4 and iPadOS 17.4. An attacker with arbitrary kernel read and write capability may be able to bypass kernel memory protections. Apple is aware of a report that this issue may have been exploited.

jos1264@social.skynetcloud.site at 2024-03-05T21:40:07.000Z ##

Apple Blunts Zero-Day Attacks With iOS 17.4 Update https://www.securityweek.com/apple-blunts-zero-day-attacks-with-ios-17-4-update/ #Mobile&Wireless #Vulnerabilities #CVE202423225 #CVE202423296 #ZeroDay #IOS174

##
jos1264@social.skynetcloud.site at 2024-03-05T21:40:05.000Z ##

Apple Blunts Zero-Day Attacks With iOS 17.4 Update https://www.securityweek.com/apple-blunts-zero-day-attacks-with-ios-17-4-update/ #Mobile&Wireless #Vulnerabilities #CVE202423225 #CVE202423296 #ZeroDay #IOS174

##
simontsui at 2024-03-07T19:00:53.906Z ##

Apple released additional security advisories, each one containing one or both of the recently disclosed exploited zero-days CVE-2024-23225 and CVE-2024-23296, which were added to the CISA KEV Catalog on 06 March 2024:

  • About the security content of macOS Monterey 12.7.4
  • About the security content of macOS Sonoma 14.4
  • About the security content of macOS Ventura 13.6.5
  • About the security content of tvOS 17.4
  • About the security content of visionOS 1.1
  • About the security content of watchOS 10.4

Edit: About the security content of Safari 17.4
 nothing exploited.

No new zero-days.

#Apple #zeroday #vulnerability #activeexploitation #eitw #CVE_2024_23225 #CVE_2024_23296 #CISA #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #KEV #vulnerability

##
simontsui at 2024-03-06T15:10:35.728Z ##

CISA adds Apple zero-days CVE-2024-23225 and CVE-2024-23296 to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog based on evidence of active exploitation.
🔗 https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2024/03/06/cisa-adds-two-known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog

#Apple #zeroday #vulnerability #activeexploitation #eitw #CVE_2024_23225 #CVE_2024_23296 #CISA #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #KEV #vulnerability

simontsui at 2024-03-05T19:46:11.555Z ##

@jullrich of SANS ISC beats the other infosec publications to the punch by reporting on the Apple zero-days CVE-2024-23225 and CVE-2024-23296 first.
🔗 https://isc.sans.edu/diary/rss/30716

#Apple #zeroday #vulnerability #activeexploitation #eitw #CVE_2024_23225 #CVE_2024_23296

##
simontsui at 2024-03-05T18:50:41.105Z ##

Apple zero-days:

  • CVE-2024-23225: memory corruption in Kernel allowed for bypassing kernel memory protections
  • CVE-2024-23296: memory corruption in RTKit allowed for bypassing kernel memory protections

Apple is aware of a report that this issue may have been exploited.

cc: @serghei @campuscodi @briankrebs @GossiTheDog @mttaggart

🔗 https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT214081 https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT214082

Apple released additional security advisories, each one containing one or both of the recently disclosed exploited zero-days CVE-2024-23225 and CVE-2024-23296, which were added to the CISA KEV Catalog on 06 March 2024:

  • About the security content of macOS Monterey 12.7.4
  • About the security content of macOS Sonoma 14.4
  • About the security content of macOS Ventura 13.6.5
  • About the security content of tvOS 17.4
  • About the security content of visionOS 1.1
  • About the security content of watchOS 10.4

##
simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-03-05T18:50:41.000Z ##

Apple zero-days:

  • CVE-2024-23225: memory corruption in Kernel allowed for bypassing kernel memory protections
  • CVE-2024-23296: memory corruption in RTKit allowed for bypassing kernel memory protections

Apple is aware of a report that this issue may have been exploited.

cc: @serghei @campuscodi @briankrebs @GossiTheDog @mttaggart

🔗 https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT214081 https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT214082

#Apple #zeroday #vulnerability #activeexploitation #eitw #CVE_2024_23225 #CVE_2024_23296

##
applsec at 2024-03-07T18:45:36.879Z ##

Apple pushed additional updates for 2 zero-days that may have been actively exploited.

🐛 CVE-2024-23225 (Kernel) additional patches:
- macOS Monterey 12.7.4
- macOS Sonoma 14.4
- macOS Ventura 13.6.5
- tvOS 17.4
- visionOS 1.1
- watchOS 10.4

- macOS Sonoma 14.4
- tvOS 17.4
- visionOS 1.1
- watchOS 10.4
